sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a combustion reaction
message_1:
What is the standard enthalpy change for the combustion of 1 mole of ethane (C2H6) given the following balanced equation: 

C2H6(g) + 7/2O2(g) -> 2CO2(g) + 3H2O(l) 

The standard enthalpies of formation for ethane, carbon dioxide, and water are -84.7 kJ/mol, -393.5 kJ/mol, and -285.8 kJ/mol, respectively.
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the combustion of 1 mole of ethane, we can use the following equation:

ΔH_combustion = Σ ΔH_f(products) - Σ ΔH_f(reactants)

For the products, we have 2 moles of CO2 and 3 moles of H2O. For the reactants, we have 1 mole of C2H6. The standard enthalpies of formation are given for each substance.

ΔH_combustion = [(2 mol CO2 × -393.5 kJ/mol CO2) + (3 mol H2O × -285.8 kJ/mol H2O)] - (1 mol C2H6 × -84.7 kJ/mol C2H6)

ΔH_combustion = [(-787 kJ) + (-857.4 kJ)] - (-84.7 kJ)

ΔH_combustion = -1644.4 kJ + 84.7 kJ

ΔH_combustion = -1559.7 kJ

The standard enthalpy change for the combustion of 1 mole of ethane (C2H6) is -1559.7 kJ.
